lines.text: Don't lose the dream!
Anybody make a move and I'll fill 'em full of lead, or my name ain't Calamity Jane!
Just 'cause it's a tall tale don't mean it ain't true.
[on seeing a beautiful swarm of butterflies]
Kind of makes it all worthwhile, don't you think?
Not as hot as the summer of '88 when the chickens laid fried eggs and the babies cried sawdust.
Does this story have a point or does it go on and on and on like this stinkin' desert?
Somebody has to do something.
We came to say goodbye, Daniel.
I knew you would.
Pecos, don't go!
Don't worry about it! You can handle things from here!
Who are you?
I'm a ring-tailed roarer. I can draw faster, shoot straighter, ride harder and drink longer than any man alive. I ride cyclones and I wrestle...
You got a name, don't you?
I'm getting' to that. I'm the rip-snortinest cowboy that ever rode north, south, east or west of the Rio Grande. I'm Pecos Bill.
I ought to plug you two right now, but I make it a rule never to kill a man on Sunday.
Today's Wednesday.
Pa, Pecos Bill ain't real.

He's out there... where there's still enough elbow room for a man to wander. He's out there... where the land is still young and wild. You don't believe me? I swear to you by the code of the West, Pecos Bill is as real as you and me. Now, you know the Code of the West don't you?
Yeah, Pa, I know.
Respect the land, defend the defenseless and don't never spit in front of women and children.
I ain't apologizin' to no ox!
This ain't over, kid! Not by a long shot!
